awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Carbon-Free Hydrogen Production by Plasma Dissociation of Hydrogen Sulfide
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is connected to creating a large-scale source of low production cost, carbon-free hydrogen. This hydrogen will be produced from hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Nearly 8 million tons of H2S are processed by the energy industry each year. Sulfur recovery units (SRUs) are used to safely manage H2S. SRUs utilize an old Claus process and are unprofitable because of high capital and operational costs, in addition to low revenues due to sulfur overproduction. In contrast to the Claus process, H2S plasma dissociation recovers sulfur and hydrogen, whereby the sulfur can be used for oil desulfurization or as a commercial product.  Dissociating H2S in plasma and producing hydrogen will make SRUs profitable and will reduce the industry's carbon dioxide emissions. This technology will diminish societal needs for fossil fuel production and increase energy security during the transition to renewable energy. The team will develop a numerical model for the high-speed, two-phase, vortex flows that will have a general academic interest and can be applied in the chemical and energy industries.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a plasma technology for the dissociation of H2S to sulfur and hydrogen, replacing Claus plants in Sulfur Recovery Units. Phase I will focus on three innovations that are critical for the H2S dissociation development program. The major goal is the high energy efficiency expressed as Specific Energy Requirement 1.5 kWh/m3. This goal will be achieved by a special design of the arc plasmatron with an extremely high speed of gas rotation that will result in hydrogen-sulfur separation in the reaction zone, the chemical equilibrium shift, and the internal recuperation of the sulfur clusterization and condensation energy. The second innovation will be the development of a gas-dynamic and chemical-kinetic model for the numerical simulation of two-phase (gas and sulfur particles) vortex flows with a high speed of rotation. Third, the stability of the cathode and plasmatron operation will be tested with different gas mixtures that imitate the composition of real flows at refineries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is a potential large-scale feedstock for inexpensive hydrogen (H2) production because, thermodynamically, the production of H2 from H2S requires 14 times less energy than from water (H2O). The potential for producing hydrogen from existing industrial H2S-handling processes could account for as much as 25% of world H2 demand. 

RedShift Energy, Inc. (RSE) is developing H2S plasma dissociation technology based on a patented robust arc plasma-based atmospheric pressure system. This development was supported by the NSF SBIR Phase I grant for the project “Carbon-Free Hydrogen Production by Plasma Dissociation of Hydrogen Sulfide”.

For over 40 years, the oil and gas industry has investigated various H2S dissociation approaches to recover hydrogen. Plasma dissociation was considered promising; however, its development hit a roadblock in the 1990s because satisfactory results were produced only using low-pressure microwave plasma. Operations with concentrated H2S at low pressure are extremely dangerous, and it is very difficult to scale up microwave plasma systems.

H2S is toxic, corrosive, combustible, and explosive (when mixed with air) gas and is a common contamination of natural and associated gases, and the major byproduct of oil desulfurization. All large refineries and most gas separation plants have a Claus-process-based sulfur recovery units (SRUs) that partially oxidizes H2S to sulfur and water. Most SRUs are unprofitable.

RSE started the H2S plasma dissociation program in 2018, long before the start of NSF support. Three generations of experimental systems based on robust electric arc discharge were developed. The NSF SBIR grant significantly raised the energy industry’s attention to the RSE plasma technology. As a result, RSE has established contacts with most major players in the oil& gas industry and with the sulfur technology providers.

Phase 1 of the NSF SBIR-supported project was focused on three innovations that will have long-term impacts on the H2S dissociation program. The first was a theoretical study and simulation of plasma chemistry and fluid dynamics of the H2S dissociation process in the electric arc plasma generator (plasmatron). The second was the development of a new more powerful plasma system that can be modified to a prototype that will be developed in Phase II for testing and demonstration in an industrial environment. The third was testing of the arc plasmatron for successful operation not only with pure H2S but also with the mixtures that represent the compositions of real H2S-based flows at refineries and gas plants. Potential customers and industrial partners indicated that the third innovation to be the most important as the technology development and optimization make sense only if they are applicable to real-world industrial mixtures.

Completion of Phase I of the project resulted in significant progress in the H2S plasma dissociation technology. A new generation experimental system was developed that allows experimenting with high H2S flow rates (up to 100 SLPM) and plasma power (up to 5 kW). These parameters correspond to the parameters of the prototype that will be developed in Phase II for testing and demonstration in an industrial environment.

Using the new plasma system, it was demonstrated and independently validated by a third-party company the capability of the arc plasma-based process to handle the H2S-based gas mixtures typical for oil and gas industries.

RSE in collaboration with its consultant and subcontractor made significant progress in understanding the plasma-chemical process inside the plasmatron. A proprietary numerical model of the process was developed. Theoretical analysis and numerical simulation models developed during Phase I improved on process understanding and showed new approaches for increasing the energy efficiency of the process. New process understanding was included in a proprietary numerical model of the process that was developed during Phase I and that will be used for future process scaling up.

Thus, RedShift Energy, Inc. successfully completed Phase I of the NSF SBIR-supported project and will submit a Phase II proposal for project continuation.
